front: What are the advantages and disadvantages of standard deviation?
back:
• Takes all values into account.
  • However, requires knowing all data, and is difficult to calculate from large data sets.

front: What are the conditions required for a binomial distribution to be used?
back:
• Fixed number of trials.
  • Constant probability of success.
  • Each trial is independent.
  • Only two possible outcomes, success or failure.

front:
What is quantitative data?
What is qualitative data?
back:
• Quantitative data is numeric data that can be measured.
  • Qualitative data is descriptive data that is meant to understand experiences, opinions and characteristics.

front: What are the advantages and disadvantages of using a mean?
back:
• Takes all values into account, and allows for further calculation of s.d.
  • However, you must know all the data, and is easily skewed by outliers.

front: How do you estimate the mean and standard deviation of grouped data?
back: You need to take the midpoint of each group and multiply by the frequency. Use this to find your mean and sums of squares. Then use s.d. formula.

front:
For a systematic random sample:
  • What is it?
  • What are the advantages?
  • What are the disadvantages?
  • Is it random?
  • Does each participant have an equal chance?
back:
• For a sample of n of population m, calculate m/n, select random number 1 to m/n, then choose every m/nth person thereafter.
  • Easy to perform on a list of names. Random enough to be effective.
  • Can be skewed if data follows a pattern matching the sequence of the chosen data. (unlikely)
  • It is not random, as not every combination of people is possible.
  • Each participant has an equal chance, if each "group" is the same size.

front: How do you know when a binomial distribution can be approximated as a normal?
back: For a binomial B(n, p), can be approximated as N(np, sqrt(np(1-p)) when np >= 5 and n(1-p) >= 5.

front: What are measures of tendency, and what are measures of spread?
back:
Measures of tendency:
  • Mean
  • Median
  • Mode

Measures of spread:
  • Range
  • Interquartile range
  • Standard deviation

front:
For an opportunity sample:
  • What is it?
  • What are the advantages?
  • What are the disadvantages?
  • Is it random?
  • Does each participant have an equal chance?
back:
• Pick the first X people you come across and ask them.
  • Ridonculously easy.
  • Absolutely going to have bias, not representative.
  • Not random.
  • Not an equal chance.

front: What are the advantages and disadvantages of using a mode?
back:
• Easy to calculate, and works with non-numeric data.
  • However, may not be unique, and may not exist. May also be unrepresentative for data with a wide range or if it is 0.

front: What are the advantages and disadvantages of a median?
back:
• Good for when there are outliers, and can be found if some data is missing.
  • However, it is difficult to estimate for grouped data.

front:
For a simple random sample:
  • What is it?
  • What are the advantages?
  • What are the disadvantages?
  • Is it random?
  • Does each participant have an equal chance?
back:
• Number participants, use random number generator, select corresponding.
  • Simple and easy. Representative.
  • Can be time consuming to do, and could mean different strata are unluckily excluded.
  • It is random.
  • Each participant is equally likely.

front:
For a cluster sample:
  • What is it?
  • What are the advantages?
  • What are the disadvantages?
  • Is it random?
  • Does each participant have an equal chance?
back:
• Divide population into geographic (or other) clusters that make them easier to sample. Then sample some of the clusters.
  • Can save time by making it easier to sample (e.g. sampling two locations of a store instead of all 1000 stores)
  • Not representative of population, may be that the cluster was an outlier, people in that cluster have similar views etc.
  • Not random, not all combinations are possible.
  • People in smaller clusters have better odds (if clusters have same size, each is equally likely)

front: What are the advantages and disadvantages of using a range?
back:
• Easy to calculate
  • However, depends only on extreme values, not appropriate for large data sets, and cannot be calculated if unknown values.

front:
For a stratified random sample:
  • What is it?
  • What are the advantages?
  • What are the disadvantages?
  • Is it random?
  • Does each participant have an equal chance?
back:
• Divide population into different strata, then sample each group individually with a sample size proportionate to the stratum size.
  • It allows you to compare between strata, as each is represented fairly.
  • Requires prior knowledge of the population, and is more complex.
  • It is not random, not every combination is possible.
  • Each participant should still have an equal chance.

front:
What % of a normal curve is within:
  • 1 sd of mean?
  • 2 sd of mean?
  • 3 sd of mean?
back:
• 68% within 1sd.
  • 95% within 2sd.
  • 99.7% within 3sd.

front:
For a quota sample:
  • What is it?
  • What are the advantages?
  • What are the disadvantages?
  • Is it random?
  • Does each participant have an equal chance?
back:
• Go around and find the first X people that fit this category, the firsts Y people that fit that category, etc.
  • Very easy to carry out. Representative of strata without knowing about the population.
  • Biased to people who are likely to be chosen for that situation.
  • Not random.
  • Not all participants have the same chance of being selected.

front: What is a parameter in stats?
back: A parameter is a numerical value attached to a population, e.g. average height of males. A parameter is estimated using statistics.

front: What is the formula for the skewness of data?
back: 3(mean - median) / standard deviation

front: How is the large data set divided?
back:
• 5 makes - BMW, Ford, Toyota, Vauxhall, VW
  • 3 regions - London, North West, South West
  • 5 propulsion types - Petrol, Diesel, Electric, Gas/Petrol, Electric/Petrol
  • 5 keeper titles - Male, Female, Not Used, Unknown (Rev, Dr etc.), Company)
  • 2 years - 2002, 2016

front: What is interesting about propulsion types in LDS?
back: Only one electric car, and only 1 gas/electric car.

front: What is interesting about the keeper titles?
back: The title "Not Used" is not ever used.

front: What units are used in the database?
back:
• Emissions = g/km
  • Mass = kg
  • Engine size = cc

front: What is interesting about the mass of the cars in LDS?
back: The mass includes a 75kg driver.

front: What are some errors in the large data set?
back: Sometimes the mass is recorded as 0kg, which is an error. Should be excluded from calculations.
